"**The Night the Lights Went Out in Georgia** " is a [Southern
Gothic](/wiki/Southern_Gothic "Southern Gothic") song, written in 1972 by
songwriter [Bobby Russell](/wiki/Bobby_Russell "Bobby Russell") and sung by
[Vicki Lawrence](/wiki/Vicki_Lawrence "Vicki Lawrence"), an American [pop
music](/wiki/Pop_music "Pop music") singer, actress, and comedian. Lawrence's
version, from her 1973 Bell Records album of the same name, was a number one
hit on the [_Billboard_ Hot 100](/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100 "Billboard Hot 100")
after its release. In addition to several other renditions, the song was again
a hit in 1991 when [Reba McEntire](/wiki/Reba_McEntire "Reba McEntire")
recorded it for her album _[For My Broken Heart](/wiki/For_My_Broken_Heart
"For My Broken Heart")_. McEntire's version was a single, as well, reaching
number 12 on [Hot Country Songs](/wiki/Hot_Country_Songs "Hot Country Songs").

##
Synopsis[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Night_the_Lights_Went_Out_in_Georgia&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Synopsis")]

A nameless man returns home after two weeks to be informed by his best friend
Andy that the man's wife has been unfaithful, sleeping with both Andy and a
third man, "that Ames boy, Seth." The man returns home and, noting his wife is
not home, heads to Andy's house with a gun; when he arrives, he finds Andy's
dead body. In an attempt to flag down the [Georgia State
Patrol](/wiki/Georgia_State_Patrol "Georgia State Patrol"), the man fires a
warning shot into the air, only to realize too late that the combination of
circumstances (the dead body, holding a gun and an audible gunshot) made him
look like the killer.

The sheriff arrests the man, a swift [show trial](/wiki/Show_trial "Show
trial") is held and the man is convicted and hanged in short order. In the
song's epilogue, the man's younger sister (singing in the [first
person](/wiki/First_person_narrative "First person narrative")) confesses that
she killed Andy as well as the man's wife, whose body was disposed where it
would never be found. The little sister blames the Georgia criminal justice
system for her brother's death, warning in each chorus "the judge in the
town's got blood stains on his hands."[1]

## History and original
recording[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Night_the_Lights_Went_Out_in_Georgia&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: History and original recording")]

Although Bobby Russell wrote both the lyrics and music for the song, he was
reluctant to record even a demonstration because he "didn't like it."
According to Lawrence, who was married to Russell at the time, she believed it
was destined to be successful and recorded the demo herself. The publishers
and the record label did not quite know how to pitch the song, as it was not
really a country or a pop song. The first thought was to offer the song to
actress/singer [Liza Minnelli](/wiki/Liza_Minnelli "Liza Minnelli"), but
eventually it was offered to singer [Cher](/wiki/Cher "Cher"), but her then-
husband and manager [Sonny Bono](/wiki/Sonny_Bono "Sonny Bono") reportedly
refused it, as he was said to be concerned that the song might offend Cher's
southern fans.[2] Without a singer to record the song, Lawrence went into a
studio and recorded it professionally herself, with the instrumental backing
of L.A. session musicians from the [Wrecking
Crew](/wiki/The_Wrecking_Crew_\(music\) "The Wrecking Crew \(music\)"),[3]
then pressed the label to release it as a single.

## Release and
reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Night_the_Lights_Went_Out_in_Georgia&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Release and reception")]

Released as a single in June 1972, the song would ultimately become a number-
one success for Lawrence, topping the Hot 100 chart in early 1973. Lawrence
was, at the time, a regular performer on the ensemble variety comedy
television show _[The Carol Burnett Show](/wiki/The_Carol_Burnett_Show "The
Carol Burnett Show")_. It scored number six on the [Easy
Listening](/wiki/Hot_Adult_Contemporary "Hot Adult Contemporary") chart,[4]
and it peaked at number 36 on _Billboard '_s Hot Country Singles chart.[5] It
was number one for two weeks on the [_Billboard_ Hot
100](/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100 "Billboard Hot 100"), and was finally topped by
[Tony Orlando and Dawn](/wiki/Tony_Orlando_and_Dawn "Tony Orlando and Dawn")'s
"[Tie a Yellow Ribbon Round the Ole Oak
Tree](/wiki/Tie_a_Yellow_Ribbon_Round_the_Ole_Oak_Tree "Tie a Yellow Ribbon
Round the Ole Oak Tree")". _Billboard_ ranked it as the [No. 11 song for
1973](/wiki/Billboard_Year-End_Hot_100_singles_of_1973 "Billboard Year-End Hot
100 singles of 1973").

In Canada, the single version scored number one, as well, topping the [_RPM_
100](/wiki/RPM_\(magazine\) "RPM \(magazine\)") national singles chart on May
5 of the same year.[6] On the RPM Country Singles chart, it reached #25.[7]

## Musical
structure[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Night_the_Lights_Went_Out_in_Georgia&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Musical structure")]

The lyrics use an AABCCB rhyming pattern on the verses, and ABCB on the
chorus. The song's verses are in C [Dorian](/wiki/Dorian_mode "Dorian mode").
Verse one consists of four lines, each using the chord pattern
Cm-Bâ™­/C-Cm-F/C-Cm-Gm7-Cm. At the chorus, the song
[modulates](/wiki/Modulation_\(music\) "Modulation \(music\)") to the key of
[G major](/wiki/G_major "G major"), with a chord pattern of Am-D7-G-Em used
three times before ending on Am-D7-Gm.[8]

Verse two uses the same structure as verse one, with an additional two lines.
The first additional lines also modulate to G major with a chord pattern of
Am-D7-G-Em-Am-D-Gm, before returning to C Dorian for another repetition of the
original chord pattern. After the second chorus, the third verse consists of
only two lines before the chorus is sung a third time. The song then ends with
a four-measure riff played in the key of [G minor](/wiki/G_minor "G minor").
The overall vocal range is G3-D5.[8]

### Tanya Tucker
cover[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Night_the_Lights_Went_Out_in_Georgia&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Tanya Tucker cover")]

In 1981, country singer [Tanya Tucker](/wiki/Tanya_Tucker "Tanya Tucker")
recorded a version (on an album of the same name) with differing lyrics and an
altered timeline. These altered lyrics were based on the plot line of the 1981
movie _[The Night the Lights Went Out in
Georgia](/wiki/The_Night_the_Lights_Went_Out_in_Georgia_\(film\) "The Night
the Lights Went Out in Georgia \(film\)")_.

### Reba McEntire
cover[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Night_the_Lights_Went_Out_in_Georgia&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Reba McEntire cover")]

During 1991, the song was sung as a cover version by [Reba
McEntire](/wiki/Reba_McEntire "Reba McEntire") on her album _For My Broken
Heart_. It reached number 12 on _Billboard '_s Hot Country Songs chart. While
still a commercially successful release, this broke a string of 24 consecutive
top 10 country singles by McEntire.

The song also had a successful music video, wherein the older brother of the
story is given the name "Raymond Brody"; the video for McEntire's version also
contained spoken dialogue that expanded on several of the song's plot points,
by suggesting that the judge knew that the narrator's brother did not commit
the crime, but was nonetheless anxious to convict him, since he, himself (the
judge) had also been having sex with the wife (played by
[Playboy](/wiki/Playboy "Playboy") centerfold/pin up model [Barbara
Moore](/wiki/Barbara_Moore_\(model\) "Barbara Moore \(model\)")) and was
worried that a long, involved trial would cause this fact to become known. It
also establishes that the little sister (played by McEntire, and portrayed
both as a young woman in flashbacks and as a 60-year-old woman using heavy
makeup) caught Andy in the act with her brother's wife and that the unfaithful
woman also had an affair with the sister's own fiancÃ©.

## In popular
culture[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Night_the_Lights_Went_Out_in_Georgia&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: In popular culture")]

  * For a 1986 _[Designing Women](/wiki/Designing_Women "Designing Women")_ episode, main character [Julia Sugarbaker](/wiki/Julia_Sugarbaker "Julia Sugarbaker") ([Dixie Carter](/wiki/Dixie_Carter_\(actress\) "Dixie Carter \(actress\)")) has one of her famous tirades, defending her beauty queen sister Suzanne against catty remarks made by a young woman, concluding with "And _that_ , just so you will know, and your children will someday know, was the night the lights went out in Georgia!"
  * It is a prime example of a [twist ending](/wiki/Twist_ending "Twist ending") in a song, and in the 1992 film _[Reservoir Dogs](/wiki/Reservoir_Dogs "Reservoir Dogs")_ , one of the mobsters in the film named [Nice Guy Eddie](/wiki/Nice_Guy_Eddie "Nice Guy Eddie") says "...this is the first time I ever realized that the girl singin' the song is the one who shot Andy."
  * The opening motif is sampled in ["The Time Is Now"](/wiki/The_Time_Is_Now_\(John_Cena_song\) "The Time Is Now \(John Cena song\)"), which is currently used as American professional wrestler [John Cena](/wiki/John_Cena "John Cena")'s entrance music; specifically, the song samples Pete Schofield and The Canadians' rendition.
  * In 2011, a book was released titled "The Night the Lights Went Out in Georgia," written by Jeremy G.T. Reuschling and casually based on the McEntire version of the song and the music video.
  * [Melinda Schneider](/wiki/Melinda_Schneider "Melinda Schneider") and [Beccy Cole](/wiki/Beccy_Cole "Beccy Cole") covered the song on their album _[Great Women of Country](/wiki/Great_Women_of_Country "Great Women of Country")_ (2014).
  * Comedy group [The Credibility Gap](/wiki/The_Credibility_Gap "The Credibility Gap") recorded a parody version, "The Night That The Lights Stayed On In Pittsburgh."
